questions.answer_description: Sprints promote iterative and incremental development.
questions.question_text: What must the Development Team do during the first Sprint?

choices.B: Analyze and estimate the requirements for the subsequent Sprints.
choices.C: Create a project plan in order to map functional development to Sprint dates.
choices.A: Create a potentially shippable product Increment that includes at least one piece of functionality.
choices.D: Only design and develop the architecture and infrastructure.

choices.B: Support the Product Owner's decision as he/she is accountable for maximizing the value of the work that the Development Team does.
choices.D: Add at least one technical architect to the Development Team to ensure the architecture can be completed in the first Sprint.
choices.C: Explain that one Sprint may be too short to finish the architecture and he should pre-allocate subsequent Sprints just in case.
choices.A: Help the Product Owner understand the value of including business functionality into every Sprint and explain to him/her that the best architecture and infrastructure emerge alongside the development of the functionality.

questions.question_text: How should a Scrum Master respond if the Product Owner plans the first Sprint to only focus on setting up the infrastructure and architecture in order to work on functionality in a subsequent Sprint?
questions.answer_description: Getting feedback from the Users and Stakeholders is a crucial activity in Scrum. It reduces waste from building items that add no value. Saying that, the best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-organizing teams.

choices.D: All of these answers are correct.
choices.B: Short enough to be able to synchronize the development work with other business events.
choices.A: Short enough to keep the business risk acceptable to the Product Owner.

choices.C: An event that cannot take more than a maximum amount of time.
choices.A: An event that starts at a specific time.
choices.D: An event that must happen by a specific time.
choices.B: An event with a minimum set time.

questions.answer_description: All events are time-boxed events, such that every event has a maximum duration. Once a Sprint begins, its duration is fixed and cannot be shortened or lengthened. The remaining events may end whenever the purpose of the event is achieved, ensuring an appropriate amount of time is spent without allowing waste in the process.

questions.question_text: When does a new Sprint begin?

choices.B: Immediately after the end of the previous Sprint.
choices.C: It depends on the Product Owner.
choices.A: Immediately after the next Sprint Planning.
